author: @neotropos
text:
Like for like living standards against real wages (after inflation and decades of currency debasement) have plummeted. That much is obvious. 
Why? Well, the individual reasons are varied and complex - they include things like the abolition of the Gold Standard, the rise of technologies, 'post-modern' modes of thinking and globalisation. 
Perhaps it can simply be summed up as the multi-organ collapse of civilisation.

author: @garyfrancis6193
text: Ay yes. In college in 1978 I rented a room in a big old two story house downtown. It had enough rooms to rent out two more upstairs and landlady lived at the back on the first floor. She was Latvian and didn’t speak much English and by then had retired as part of the cleaning staff at the General hospital. She told me once she had bought the house in 1952 for $7000 and paid it off in 5 years. That house is still there but she is gone as she was about 70 in 1978. Now $7000 would  be your monthly mortgage payment.  It’s not that prices went up. The value of your money has decreased since 1952 by 80%. What would have cost $1 in 1952 costs $20 now and rising as your dollar keeps shrinking in value to nothing. What it amounts to is that you likely worked to get that money that is becoming more worthless every day. You can’t take back your labour so you are basically being robbed of its past value until you have nothing. In the past people bought real estate to hedge their savings against inflation and live in it too. But taxes on it and insurance kept rising and house prices kept rising relative to incomes until it is increasingly unaffordable to more and more people. That means of preserving the value of their savings is now unavailable as their money keeps dropping in value. Now big business is looking at replacing hundreds of thousands or millions of workers with AI and robots. So you won’t have income anymore. Forget about UBI. No one will be paying income tax because they will have no jobs. Where would UBI money come from? That’s the future you are facing now. What happens when people have no jobs to go to and have nothing to lose?

author: @ericroll
text: Trickle Down Economics at work. Remember when politicians no longer used the words "rich" or "wealthy" to describe a person?  Tax breaks went to the wealthy, not because they were rich, but because they were "job creators".  The downward trend for middle-income earners that began in the early 1980s wasn't too obvious because families went from 1 income to 2 incomes in order to maintain their lifestyle. Credit card use also became quite popular as a way to mask the downward spiral.

author: @jubiliejoy1845
text: Back in the 70s there was a recession. My dad was in the middle class upper middle class in the 60s and we had whatever we wanted even at Christmas. Then came the 70s and the recession. My father was laid off from his high paying job and had to take work at a factory. It was Columbia Records. Life changed at my home. They had to buy a smaller cheaper home. My dad eventually got his job back but a substantial pay cut. My  father was getting older and had lost his seniority during his factory job. They were hiring younger workers at lower pay. Life was never again the same for us. You can only say the economy was great in 70s unless you lived through them. Lots of people lost their jobs and one way or another had pay cuts. There were gas shortages and also race riots in my high school. Before your next video study your history.

author: @crawdadad
text:
If the income disparity is due to government policy decisions then why is the same income inequality happening in India, China, Germany and Nigeria?  I picked these countries randomly and ran them through Perplexity and same trends. I also asked about Brazil and Perplexity said that they bucked the trend recently. Of course it said that Brazil was already one of the top countries in income inequality and wealth disparity already. 

Economic growth vs Individual living standards. Everyone has a cellphone. We all live longer. Lots of babies survive today due to medical care for premature babies. We have a much larger state. When I was growing up the air was polluted, rivers were flammable, playground equipment and cars were deadly and our houses were filled with poisonous materials. Our pesticides were killing us and everything else. Larger, much more. In nominal dollars federal government expenditures, not even counting entitlements, is 71x!  And you didn’t even mention the creation of Medicare. Spending on Social Security and Medicare are now HUNDREDS of times greater!  A lot of the income disparity is being offset by government spending.
You said that women entering the workforce was necessary. Not sure about that. All sexes of all racial groups are now competing for the same jobs. And immigration is off the charts compared to 1955. I feel like you’re telling a story, but not THE story. 
Social security outlays in billions 
1955 $7.8 
1960 $11.2
1970 $30.9
1980 $118.6
1990 $248.6
2000 $409.4
2010 $706.7
2020 $1906
2024 $1458

The rich aren’t getting all that money.

author: @Nuonerew
text:
Yes, the citizens of the USA bear the cost of US government subsidies. 
Here's how:
Taxpayer Funding: Government subsidies are funded by taxpayer money, collected through various forms of taxation. In effect, citizens' tax payments contribute to the resources that are then allocated as subsidies.
Borrowing: If a subsidy program is financed through government borrowing, the costs are borne by future taxpayers, including the interest payments associated with the debt.
Economic Impact: The act of funding subsidies through taxes or borrowing can have negative economic effects on individuals and businesses, impacting their working, investing, and entrepreneurial activities. 
In essence, citizens, as taxpayers, ultimately provide the funds for government subsidies, and their economic activities can be affected by the costs and potential economic distortions associated with these programs.

author: @Nuonerew
text:
US government subsidies are financial assistance programs that provide support to individuals, businesses, or industries to achieve specific economic or social goals. These subsidies can take the form of direct cash payments, tax breaks, or other forms of support. They are often intended to encourage certain activities, offset costs, or promote specific sectors of the economy. 
Here's a more detailed explanation:
Purpose:
Subsidies are used to influence market outcomes, encourage specific behaviors, or address market failures. They can be used to make goods and services more affordable, stimulate economic activity, or support industries deemed important for national security or public well-being.

author: @HichigoShirosaki1
text:
This doesn't pinpoint the exact time the graphs diverge at which point is the root cause, which would show how to reverse it. What I can say, though, is that automation, telecommunications, women in the workforce, and the baby boom are the primary causes because more workers, whether automated, outsourced, or adding more people to the workforce, mean more supply mean less pay per person and not everyone was in a household with another person to mitigate that. Simply put, productivity mainly benefits the rich because they make more profit the more goods their businesses move which is the exact sane concept as gdp. VOLUME = $$$. That is basic business economics. When they could only choose from suitable men to do jobs and can't outsource to somewhere cheaper, take the men out of the equation through automation, and can't decide to just hire a woman, they don't have leverage for cheaper labor. That is part of why tarrifs are actually a solid idea to mitigate some of it.

 There are several graphs you could have shown to better analyze the issue that goes over the actual economics involved. This video sounds more like an overview rather than an actual analysis, which is needed to really answer the question. 

Another point here as well is that this is just looking at numbers, not the people themselves. The numbers changing do not necessarily mean it is more difficult. Some people are outliers, but it's why they are outliers that matter.

author: @manderse12
text:
Very helpful.  Thank you.  ...But there are four sets of really important details missing from your account that would allow people to ACT ON this information: 
1) Which policies exactly made this wealth disparity a reality?  
2) What are the alternative policies that we can feasibly push through congress (given the imbalance in real lobbying power that exists today)?
3) What about the sustainability picture (i.e., all the hidden costs that are buried in the economic data that mask the damage we have done--and will continue to do--to the natural environment that makes life possible)?  Economists have always obscured and papered over these hidden costs--like pollution, greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, biodiversity and habitat loss--that affect us now and all future generations of living organisms.  (Humans are not the only species that matter for measuring well-being, of course.) 
4) What does a truly sustainable economy look like (because pretending that we could alter policies that improve only human well-being is a lie that we can't afford to believe anymore).

author: @theregularviking-eg2od
text: It's interesting to note that the 1960's wasn't investigated more fully. The cultural revolution, JFK's assassination, and LBJ's Social Security Amendments act all were huge contributors to the economic quagmire we live in today. To my mind, this decade set the stage for things like Enron, Bernie Madoff, and a ton of others that I'm not mentioning or have yet to be caught. I understand that it's a cultural tightrope to walk this line, but maybe everyone is wrong. In the 1950's, blacks from the West Indies were doing fantastic (and still are). Quite frankly (not to sound too ethereal) I think it goes back to Magna Carta. If everyone is subject to the law (including the King or what have you), then what has been done since... a while ago (I'm not going there as it would take too long) is to just make so many laws, amendments, etc. that the definition of what the law defines is so muddied that it could mean anything. And that (obviously) points at the last few years concerning everything to..... well, you know what I'm saying (hopefully). Great video! Cheers!

text: There are a number of factors this does not consider. We have to keep in mind that the percentage of people in the high income category is very small so once this money is divided up to so many, it likely isn't going to make a lot of difference. Also the definition of productivity needs to be looked at. In a service based economy, most supposed productivity is just paper shuffling that doesn't actually produce any real wealth. It doesn't build houses, cars or furniture or provide us with health that we consider our most cherished possessions.

author: @ChrisLeonard-np7lh
text:
In the Seventies I worked as a nurses aide to put myself through college. My tuition was $250/quarter at a state school. I made $2.50 an hour. I paid $50/month to rent a third floor room. I could afford a nice used cars, a Gran Torino. I took 2 week long vacations to CA.
Things were starting to fall apart though. Here’s the story of the Rust Belt where I lived in the Seventies and early Eighties. Billy Joel’s Allentown.
https://youtu.be/BHnJp0oyOxs?si=AmZcIA43jSmLbV0k

author: @ChrisLeonard-np7lh
text: In 1956 my single mom who worked as a clerk and part time bookkeeper in a drug store bought a small but nice 2 BR in a great suburb outside Cleveland for 11K. She bought a new Ford Falcon in 1960. We took vacations to Chicago, Niagara Falls, Wisconsin Dells. Parochial school was free. We played outside and rode our bikes all over town.
